node.text:
This video will help you prepare for using the recreation.gov mobile site to purchase a Going-to-the-Sun Road ticket. Tickets are limited and can sell out before you get one even if you are prepared, but knowing how to use the site puts you in the best position to successfully acquire one.

To learn more about ticketed entry visit our website, https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/gtsrticketedentry.htm.

node.title: How To Get a $2 Going-to-the-Sun Road

node.text: On Science Friday this week, we learn all about the loon banding project happening here in Northwest Montana. We then get to go out--at night--to bring you a firsthand look at what it takes to capture and band loons! #ScienceFriday #ParkScience #wildlifebio

node.text:
Glacier National Park is classified as a Class 1 airshed under the Clean Air Act. This designation affords the highest level of air quality protection provided under the Act. 

Fresh air, dramatic views, and pristine water are some of the qualities that draw visitors to Glacier from all over the world. Air quality in the park affects obvious things, like visibility. It also has less obvious impacts - on water quality, forest composition and ecosystem function. 

Glacier has had a permanent air quality monitoring site since 1980. The site includes devices and networks that measure different components of the atmosphere. 

Join us for this Science Friday, as the park's Physical Scientist shows us around the site and explains how we measure air quality in Glacier! 

#ScienceFriday #ScienceInParks #GlacierNationalPark #ParkScience #AirQuality

node.title: Science Friday- What's in the Air?

node.text:
You probably expect that Glacier protects things like bears and rivers. Did you know, though, that the park also protects and preserves over 700 historic structures?

Welcome back to Season Two of Science Fridays with Ranger Melissa! We are so excited to continue exploring, learning, and discovering science and research in the park with you! 
This week, we learn about historic buildings in Glacier from the park's historical architect, Kim Hyatt.

node.title: Science Friday - Historic Buildings of Glacier

node.text:
Have you missed us? Science Friday with Ranger Melissa is back with a great final Science Friday video for you! This week, Melissa goes out with John Waller, the park’s bear biologist, to explore the trail for signs of bears, discover differences between bears in Glacier and elsewhere, and learn about how bears live at different times of year. 

#ParkScience #ScienceFriday #Bears #Hibernation #GlacierNationalPark #WildlifeBiology #ScienceInParks

node.title: Science Friday - Glacier's Bears with John Waller

node.text: This week, we are bringing you a VERY special Science Friday. Ranger Melissa travels to an active archaeological site on the east side of the park to meet with archaeologist Brent Rowley. A river has been eroding away the bank, revealing some incredible things about the history of this place. Watch more to find out what they discover! #sciencefriday #parkscience #archaeology #scienceinparks #glaciernationalpark

node.title: Science Friday - Archaeological discovery with Brent Rowley

node.text: Learning about the special connection Native Peoples have to Glacier National Park can expand the way you think about this place. Visit the park’s official website to see more videos like this.

node.title: “We Are the Owners of Glacier National Park”

node.accessibility_caption: Mountains and their reflection in a lake.

node.text:
Some say that there are two seasons in Montana: winter and construction. While visiting Glacier this year, you may experience delays due to road construction.

Returning visitors to Many Glacier Valley may recall the rough road and its many bumps and potholes. Underneath its surface, soil slides and slumps have occurred as the earth beneath the road has crept downslope, particularly when saturated. Soil movement increased after the construction of Sherburne Dam (1914-1921), and when Many Glacier Road was constructed (1927-1928), three slides started to form immediately. The frequent patches and repairs since then have added more pavement material, increasing the weight of the road, causing greater amounts of soil movement. The road crews’ project there this year has aimed for a long-term solution to these issues by both increasing soil water drainage underneath the road and fully rebuilding the road surface. Because of this, the road accessing Many Glacier remains under construction, and delays of 40 minutes can be expected from Babb to the end of Many Glacier Road. Longer delays (up to 3 hours) should be expected to enter or exit this area between 10 pm and 5 am.

On the west side of the park, major construction on Camas Road has now begun, which includes the building of a new entry station. If visitors are planning on traveling from Polebridge to the Apgar area, they should expect delays of about 20 minutes during the day. A portion of Camas Road is closed to all traffic (hiking, biking, and vehicles) from 7 pm to 6 am each night for the next three weeks. This four-mile stretch is between the turnoff to Fish Creek and just south of the Huckleberry Fire Lookout Trail. To see current conditions on all of the road construction projects occurring in and around the park, please see our website: https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/2021projectwork.htm.

node.text:
This video will help you prepare for using the recreation.gov mobile site to purchase a Going-to-the-Sun Road ticket. Tickets are limited and can sell out before you get one even if you are prepared, but knowing how to use the site puts you in the best position to successfully acquire one.

To learn more about ticketed entry visit our website, https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/gtsrticketedentry.htm.

node.accessibility_caption: Tent cabins, tipi, and corral near the shore of Cosley Lake. Women and men in boots and cowboy hats sit on fence and chat amongst themselves as wrangler readies horses.

node.text:
In Glacier’s early days, tent camps run by private concessioners provided food and lodging to visitors traveling on horseback throughout the park. The first tent camps were created with the support of the Great Northern Railway and were often precursors to their backcountry chalets constructed at the same locations. Later, the Park Saddle Horse Company established four “permanent” camps in scenic areas of the park that helped support the trail network connecting the Railway’s chalets and hotels.

This photo taken sometime between 1940 and 1965 shows the tent camp at Cosley Lake (then sometimes known as Crossley Lake) in Glacier’s Belly River region. Other tent camps were constructed at Red Eagle Lake, Goat Haunt, and Fifty Mountain. With this network of tent camps, chalets, and front-country hotels, visitors could expect comfortable accommodations to be no more than one day’s ride apart on horseback.

Like most of the backcountry chalets (except for those at Sperry and Granite Park), the tent camps did not survive the Depression and World War II. Saddle horse trips declined as private automobiles became the preferred mode of transportation and the tent camps were all eventually dismantled. #tbt #throwbackthursday

node.text:
Consistent with CDC guidance regarding areas of substantial or high transmission, visitors to Glacier National Park, regardless of vaccination status, are required to wear a mask inside all park buildings.

#RecreateResponsibly

node.accessibility_caption: A snowy mountain with purple evening light and shadows on it.

node.text:
In Glacier, stunning mountain views are never far away.

The Livingston Range to the west and the Lewis Range to the east provide a vast wonderland of glacially carved peaks and valleys. Millions of years of geologic forces have shaped the landscape into the scenic vistas enjoyed by countless visitors. Evidence of these forces can be seen in the folded and fractured rocks that are visible in Glacier's mountainsides today.

What is your favorite mountain view in Glacier?

node.accessibility_caption: A pinecone with its scales open, showing that it has released its seeds. It is slightly singed on one side.

node.text:
Most plant species in fire-prone ecosystems are adapted to fire in some way. But lodgepole pines are especially clever! 

Some of their cones are sealed with a resin that melts at high temperatures—these are called serotinous cones. They rely on fire to melt the resin and release the seeds so that new trees can grow.

But not all lodgepole cones are serotinous. Lodgepole pine forests generally burn every 150-300 years, in high-intensity fires that kill most of the mature trees—and lodgepoles have evolved to take advantage of this. 

Young lodgepoles have almost all non-serotinous cones, which open and release their seeds without fire. But as the trees grow older, especially towards 150 years of age, a higher proportion of their cones become serotinous. Essentially, the trees are betting that a fire is more likely, and putting more of their energy and seeds into serotinous cones. 

What other fire-adapted species can you think of?

Photo caption: these images show lodgepole pine cones. One image shows two sealed, unopened cones, and the other shows a cone after it has burned and opened, releasing its seeds.

node.accessibility_caption: A pinecone with its scales open, showing that it has released its seeds. It is slightly singed on one side.
Two pinecones are tightly sealed, with the seeds inside.
Two uniformed rangers working a crosscut saw into a downed log.

node.text:
"Chainsaws are work. Crosscut saws are exercise."

For hundreds of years, if you had to cut a downed log or fell a tree, the crosscut saw was your tool of choice. Early trail builders and fire crews in Glacier used the saws extensively. 

By the 1950s, chainsaws began to take their place, and manufacturing of crosscut saws nearly halted.

Vintage crosscut saws require more space to operate than a chainsaw, often require two people, and require specialized maintenance. However, these old saws are still a favorite tool of trail crews today. Why?

🌲 For one thing, they are the best tool for use in designated wilderness areas, where chainsaw use is prohibited. 
💪 They're easier to travel with, weighing less and requiring no fuel. 
🔥 Sawyers can also use them during Stage II fire restrictions which limit chainsaw use—restrictions currently in place at Glacier.

In keeping with the park's recommended wilderness designation, wilderness rangers (certified in crosscut use) carry these 1 and 2-person saws with them throughout Glacier today. 

Have you ever used one?

node.accessibility_caption: Two uniformed rangers working a crosscut saw into a downed log.
A close-up of the lanced-tooth pattern of teeth on a cross-cut saw.
A crosscut saw 2/3rds of the way through a log, with an orange wedge holding the log apart.
A closeup of a one-person crosscut saw's champion tooth pattern.
A crosscut saw halfway through a log.
Gloved hands working a crosscut saw through a log.
A wood sign that says "Glacier National Park" on a stone base with forest and blue sky in the background.

node.text:
Effective Monday, July 26, Stage 2 Fire Restrictions are in effect in Glacier National Park.

To learn about Stage 2 Fire Restrictions, and to stay up to date about fire information in the park, visit: https://www.nps.gov/glac/learn/nature/fire-information.htm

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on July 24, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Glacier provides visitors from all over the world with great opportunities to view iconic North American wildlife. What species are you hoping to see during your visit?

Many immediately think of large mammals, including mountain goats and bighorn sheep. While seeing these animals in their natural habitat is something truly memorable and exciting, we humans must remember that we are all visitors in their homes.

When observing wildlife, there are two main rules for us to follow: (1) do not feed the animals, even on accident, and (2) maintain a safe viewing distance between your party and the wildlife. For bears and wolves, maintain 100 yards in distance. For all other wildlife, including sheep and goats, maintain 25 yards. Please help us keep Glacier’s wildlife wild, and Glacier’s visitors (including yourself) safe during your encounters!

Many people see mountain goats and bighorn sheep up at the higher elevations of the park, with the most accessible alpine area being Logan Pass. Rangers use several methods to reduce the potential for dangerous human-wildlife interactions here. This includes hiring one of our most charismatic employees, a border collie named Gracie! Gracie helps herd the sheep and goats away from crowded areas like parking lots to maintain safe viewing distances for everyone involved – both animals and people.

node.accessibility_caption: A shuttle bus with a readerboard that says Logan Pass and forest and mountain in the background.

node.text:
Don't forget that Glacier National Park’s Ticket-to-Ride shuttle system will be in operation through Labor Day weekend this year!

To ensure buses can run at the proper capacity, shuttles require a $1 ticket purchased through recreation.gov. Advance tickets went on sale June 1; additional tickets are released each morning at 8 am MDT for the shuttles two days later. More shuttle tickets are made available as capacity allows, so if you didn’t get a ticket initially keep checking back on recreation.gov—new tickets often become available! 

For more information on Glacier’s shuttles and how Ticket-to-Ride works, visit: https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/shuttles.htm.

node.accessibility_caption: A cluster of small wooden buildings stand in a clearing recently burned over by a fire with mountains in the background.]

node.text:
One of the most significant fires in the history of Glacier National Park was the Heavens Peak Fire of August 1936. It started on August 18, when lightning struck a tree on the southeastern shoulder of Heavens Peak. When the smoke was discovered on August 21, men were sent out to suppress the fire. But the precipitous nature of the terrain made it very difficult to control; it had reached an area of approximately 200 acres before the spread was stopped.

Firefighters thought they had the blaze contained when, on August 30, high winds came up and revived the fire. The flames jumped the control lines and moved toward Granite Park and Swiftcurrent Pass. The following day it reached Granite Park (fortunately sparing the chalet there) and by that evening it had crossed Swiftcurrent Pass and was roaring down the Many Glacier Valley. In a matter of hours it reached the Many Glacier Hotel, which was saved thanks to the efforts of the hotel employees.

While the hotel survived, the fire destroyed most of the original Many Glacier chalets and many of the Swiftcurrent Motor Inn cabins, along with the Many Glacier ranger station, the new park museum just constructed the year before, and other buildings around Swiftcurrent Lake.

A change in the wind and weather stopped the blaze before it had a chance to go much farther, and firefighting crews were then able to move in and prevent its further spread and damage. The fire burned approximately 7,500 acres and completely denuded much of the Many Glacier valley. It also led to the construction of fire lookouts on Swiftcurrent Mountain and Heavens Peak.

This photo, taken a year later in 1937, shows the newly re-constructed Many Glacier Ranger Station and surrounding buildings in an area cleared by the fire. It is a stark contrast to what this area looks like today, as these buildings are now surrounded by trees once again. #tbt #throwbackthursday

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park in Glacier National Park. May be an image of car and road.

node.text:
It’s not too late to snag a Going-to-the-Sun Road ticket this summer!

Tickets are still available on recreation.gov for the last five days of ticketed entry, September 2-6. After September 6, tickets are not required to access Going-to-the-Sun Road. Additional tickets are released 48 hours in advance for each day of ticketed entry.

For more information on how to purchase Going-to-the-Sun Road Entry Reservation Tickets see the link in our story!
